articles.headline: Roger Stone Is Convicted of Impeding Investigators in a Bid to Protect Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Stone, a longtime informal adviser to President Trump, obstructed one of Congress’s Russia investigations and lied to lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Mr. Stone, a longtime informal adviser to President Trump, obstructed one of Congress’s Russia investigations and lied to lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, Roger J. Stone Jr. played politics as a kind of performance art, starring himself as a professional lord of mischief, as a friend once called him. He tossed bombs and spun tales from the political periphery with no real reckoning, burnishing a reputation as a dirty trickster.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Zach Montague

articles.headline: What Ads Are Political? Twitter Struggles With a Definition
articles.snippet: Twitter has said it will ban all political ads. But what is or isn’t a political message is often in the eye of the beholder.
articles.abstract: Twitter has said it will ban all political ads. But what is or isn’t a political message is often in the eye of the beholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Alzheimer’s Association, a health care advocacy group, recently spent $84,000 on ad campaigns on Twitter. One campaign had a singular purpose: to persuade people to ask Congress for larger investments in medical research for the disease.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger

articles.headline: Ex-Envoy to Ukraine ‘Devastated’ as Trump Vilified Her
articles.snippet: As Marie Yovanovitch testified, President Trump tweeted insults at her, drawing charges of witness intimidation.
articles.abstract: As Marie Yovanovitch testified, President Trump tweeted insults at her, drawing charges of witness intimidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former United States ambassador to Ukraine told the House impeachment inquiry on Friday that she felt threatened by President Trump and “shocked, appalled, devastated” that he vilified her in a call with another foreign leader, as Mr. Trump attacked her in real time on Twitter, drawing a stern warning about witness intimidation from Democrats.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Ethnic Rifts in Bolivia Burst Into View With Fall of Evo Morales
articles.snippet: As the country’s first Indigenous president has tumbled from power, Indigenous Bolivians fear the loss of their hard-won political gains, and say a racial backlash has begun.
articles.abstract: As the country’s first Indigenous president has tumbled from power, Indigenous Bolivians fear the loss of their hard-won political gains, and say a racial backlash has begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: COCHABAMBA, Bolivia — In the days since the ouster of Evo Morales, Bolivia’s first Indigenous president, deep ethnic tensions that have long divided the country have erupted, complicating efforts to move Bolivia out of political crisis.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Trump Clears Three Service Members in War Crimes Cases
articles.snippet: The moves signaled that as commander in chief, Mr. Trump intends to use his power as the ultimate arbiter of military justice.
articles.abstract: The moves signaled that as commander in chief, Mr. Trump intends to use his power as the ultimate arbiter of military justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump cleared three members of the armed services on Friday who have been accused or convicted of war crimes, overruling military leaders who had sought to punish them. All three have been championed by conservative lawmakers and commentators, who have portrayed them as war heroes unfairly prosecuted for actions taken in the heat and confusion of battle.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps

articles.headline: F.A.A. Chief Urges Employees to Resist Pressure to End Max’s Grounding
articles.snippet: His video message acknowledged “a lot of pressure to return this aircraft to service” but told workers to “focus solely on safety.”
articles.abstract: His video message acknowledged “a lot of pressure to return this aircraft to service” but told workers to “focus solely on safety.”
articles.lead_paragraph: As the grounding of Boeing’s 737 Max enters its eighth month, the company has been pressing the Federal Aviation Administration to speed up its approval of a fix that is necessary to return the plane to service.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: Labeled ‘Bad News’ by the President, an Ambassador Headlines a Bad Day for Trump
articles.snippet: In an impeachment hearing, Marie L. Yovanovitch expressed disbelief that an American president would call her “bad news” in a call with a foreign leader.
articles.abstract: In an impeachment hearing, Marie L. Yovanovitch expressed disbelief that an American president would call her “bad news” in a call with a foreign leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “In my line of work, perhaps in your line of work as well, all we have is our reputation,” Marie L. Yovanovitch, the ousted American ambassador to Ukraine, said on Friday. “This has been a very painful period.”
articles.byline: By Mark Leibovich

articles.headline: Two Female Writers Quit Patricia Heaton’s CBS Show After Making Complaints
articles.snippet: “None of this had to happen”: The network’s new sexual harassment policy did not prevent them from leaving after accusations against the star’s husband, a producer.
articles.abstract: “None of this had to happen”: The network’s new sexual harassment policy did not prevent them from leaving after accusations against the star’s husband, a producer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May, CBS employees received an email introducing a new plan for handling sexual harassment complaints. There would be a “very expanded and visible” structure, the email said, with “highly trained HR executives” at every CBS program to “ensure safety and build trust."
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and John Koblin

articles.headline: ‘Absolutely No Mercy’: Leaked Files Expose How China Organized Mass Detentions of Muslims
articles.snippet: More than 400 pages of internal Chinese documents provide an unprecedented inside look at the crackdown on ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang region.
articles.abstract: More than 400 pages of internal Chinese documents provide an unprecedented inside look at the crackdown on ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang region.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 400 pages of internal Chinese documents provide an unprecedented inside look at the crackdown on ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang region.
articles.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Bolton and Trump Met Privately Over Withheld Aid, White House Official Testified
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton, who left the White House in September, has emerged as perhaps the most conspicuous witness who has evaded House Democrats as they build their case.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton, who left the White House in September, has emerged as perhaps the most conspicuous witness who has evaded House Democrats as they build their case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John R. Bolton, President Trump’s national security adviser, met privately with the president in August as part of a bid to persuade Mr. Trump to release $391 million in security assistance to Ukraine, a senior National Security Council aide told House impeachment investigators last month.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: When the Judge Became the Defendant
articles.snippet: Judge Shelley Joseph, charged with obstruction of justice and accused of helping an undocumented immigrant escape detention, has signaled she will risk a trial.
articles.abstract: Judge Shelley Joseph, charged with obstruction of justice and accused of helping an undocumented immigrant escape detention, has signaled she will risk a trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Mass. — When she was brought before a court this spring, charged with the  federal crime of obstruction of justice, Judge Shelley Joseph did not look like a rebel.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: In Louisiana, a Narrow Win for John Bel Edwards and a Hard Loss for Trump
articles.snippet: John Bel Edwards of Louisiana, a rare Democratic governor in the South, was re-elected for a second term, beating back a challenger heavily supported by President Trump.
articles.abstract: John Bel Edwards of Louisiana, a rare Democratic governor in the South, was re-elected for a second term, beating back a challenger heavily supported by President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana, the only Democratic governor in the Deep South, narrowly won re-election Saturday, overcoming the intervention of President Trump, who visited the state multiple times in an effort to help Mr. Edwards’s Republican challenger and demonstrate his own clout.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Jeremy Alford

articles.headline: How FedEx Cut Its Tax Bill to $0
articles.snippet: The company, like much of corporate America, has not made good on its promised investment surge from President Trump’s 2017 tax cuts.
articles.abstract: The company, like much of corporate America, has not made good on its promised investment surge from President Trump’s 2017 tax cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the 2017 fiscal year, FedEx owed more than $1.5 billion in taxes. The next year, it owed nothing. What changed was the Trump administration’s tax cut — for which the company had lobbied hard.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Peter Eavis and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: How Elizabeth Warren Got to ‘Yes’ on Medicare for All
articles.snippet: Health care had not been a driving issue for the Massachusetts senator. But the expansive $20.5 trillion package could come to define her candidacy anyway.
articles.abstract: Health care had not been a driving issue for the Massachusetts senator. But the expansive $20.5 trillion package could come to define her candidacy anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days before Senator Elizabeth Warren rolled out a fundamental reimagining of America’s health care and tax system — a $20.5 trillion package that would dwarf all her previous plans combined — she was working the phones to personally preview her proposal and sell it to a select group of political influencers.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Sarah Kliff and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Michael Bloomberg Pushed ‘Stop-and-Frisk’ Policing. Now He’s Apologizing.
articles.snippet: Ahead of a possible Democratic run for president, the former mayor of New York City reversed himself before an important party constituency: black voters.
articles.abstract: Ahead of a possible Democratic run for president, the former mayor of New York City reversed himself before an important party constituency: black voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ahead of a potential Democratic presidential run, former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York on Sunday reversed his longstanding support of the aggressive “stop-and-frisk” policing strategy that he pursued for a decade and that led to the disproportionate stopping of black and Latino people across the city.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: For Start-Ups, Cash Is King (Again)
articles.snippet: Some are preparing for a potential downturn by cutting spending and raising money earlier than planned. Just as they did before.
articles.abstract: Some are preparing for a potential downturn by cutting spending and raising money earlier than planned. Just as they did before.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Frank, who runs a health technology start-up called SonderMind, had planned to wait until the end of 2020 to raise more money for his company.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: WeWork May Lay Off Thousands
articles.snippet: The beleaguered office space company is said to be planning to cut its work force by at least a third in a bid to stabilize its business.
articles.abstract: The beleaguered office space company is said to be planning to cut its work force by at least a third in a bid to stabilize its business.
articles.lead_paragraph: WeWork is preparing to cut at least 4,000 people from its work force as it tries to stabilize itself after the company’s breakneck growth racked up heavy losses and led it to the brink of collapse, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Ford Wants to Sell You an Electric S.U.V. It’s Called a Mustang.
articles.snippet: Automakers have made battery-powered cars largely to meet environmental rules. Now they’re putting more skin in the game.
articles.abstract: Automakers have made battery-powered cars largely to meet environmental rules. Now they’re putting more skin in the game.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ford Motor’s latest offering seems like an oxymoron twice over: It’s a sport utility vehicle that’s electric … that’s a Mustang.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: The Iran Cables: Secret Documents Show How Tehran Wields Power in Iraq
articles.snippet: Hundreds of leaked intelligence reports shed light on a shadow war for regional influence — and the battles within the Islamic Republic’s own spy divisions
articles.abstract: Hundreds of leaked intelligence reports shed light on a shadow war for regional influence — and the battles within the Islamic Republic’s own spy divisions
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of leaked intelligence reports shed light on a shadow war for regional influence — and the battles within the Islamic Republic’s own spy divisions
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, James Risen, Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Murtaza Hussain

articles.headline: TikTok’s Chief Is on a Mission to Prove It’s Not a Menace
articles.snippet: Alex Zhu, the head of the Chinese-owned viral video app, is trying to assuage Washington’s fears. “I am quite optimistic,” he said.
articles.abstract: Alex Zhu, the head of the Chinese-owned viral video app, is trying to assuage Washington’s fears. “I am quite optimistic,” he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like almost everybody who runs a big tech company these days, Alex Zhu, the head of the of-the-moment video app TikTok, is worried about an image problem.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: ‘No One Believes Anything’: Voters Worn Out by a Fog of Political News
articles.snippet: Paying attention to the impeachment inquiry and other developments means having to figure out what is true, false or spin. Many Americans are throwing up their hands and tuning it all out.
articles.abstract: Paying attention to the impeachment inquiry and other developments means having to figure out what is true, false or spin. Many Americans are throwing up their hands and tuning it all out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In upstate New York, Travis Trudell got an alert on his phone Wednesday morning telling him the impeachment hearings had started. He turned on Disney Plus instead. In Wisconsin, Jerre Corrigan never considered watching. She spent the day giving a math lesson to third graders. In Idaho, Russell Memory worked a busy day as a computer programmer and figured he’d catch up in a few weeks when the hearings were over.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Aidan Gardiner

articles.headline: The White Nationalist Websites Cited by Stephen Miller
articles.snippet: Newly released emails show President Trump’s chief immigration adviser was a young Senate aide who promoted his anti-immigrant views by referring to the sites.
articles.abstract: Newly released emails show President Trump’s chief immigration adviser was a young Senate aide who promoted his anti-immigrant views by referring to the sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Peter Brimelow, the founder of the anti-immigration website VDARE, believes that diversity has weakened the United States, and that the increase in Spanish speakers is a “ferocious attack on the living standards of the American working class.”
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Jason DeParle

articles.headline: He Wrote ‘Kill All Women,’ but a Judge Returned His Guns
articles.snippet: Authorities around the country have collided with the limits of laws designed to seize weapons from those who might be a threat to public safety.
articles.abstract: Authorities around the country have collided with the limits of laws designed to seize weapons from those who might be a threat to public safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — The authorities in the Seattle area came across an alarming photo on social media at the beginning of October. It showed a man holding two AK-47-style rifles. The caption above read: “one ticket for joker please.”
articles.byline: By Mike Baker

articles.headline: T-Mobile’s Longtime C.E.O., John Legere, Will Step Down
articles.snippet: Mr. Legere was credited with reviving the telecommunications company. He has been instrumental in navigating T-Mobile’s pending merger deal with Sprint.
articles.abstract: Mr. Legere was credited with reviving the telecommunications company. He has been instrumental in navigating T-Mobile’s pending merger deal with Sprint.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Legere, the chief executive of T-Mobile since 2012, was the public face of the company and its biggest cheerleader. He tirelessly promoted T-Mobile’s price promotions and gleefully bashed its rivals before his millions of followers on social media.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee
